title: Germany’s plan to control its own data
text:
Berlin aspires to become a world leader in industrial or business-to-business data technology | Yann Schreiber/AFP via Getty Images Germany’s plan to control its own data Europe’s largest economy relies on foreign cloud providers to store sensitive data. Leaders say that needs to change.

BERLIN — German lawmakers and industry leaders warn their country is too dependent on foreign-owned digital infrastructure — and they have a plan to break free.

The strategy, which includes a project to develop a European cloud-hosting service named Gaia-X, aims to address growing alarm over the reliance of large firms, government services and even police forces on hosts such as Amazon to store their data.

Berlin is gathering support for its idea across Europe, with France signing on last week to the idea of a European cloud infrastructure that would allow companies to store sensitive data with homegrown providers. The effort comes amid a broader push by European Commission President-elect Ursula von der Leyen to bolster the bloc’s “strategic autonomy” — defending EU interests thanks to a stronger home-grown industry, more innovative technology and more powerful defense capabilities.

The ability to store sensitive information with trusted hosts, or cloud providers, is seen as particularly key to German interests.

Control over data is as crucial as oil and gas for industry.

Berlin aspires to become a world leader in industrial or business-to-business data technology, a goal that senior industrialists argue will be difficult to achieve if foreign powers control the storage of sensitive data and can use their supremacy to pressure Germany.

In that sense at least, control over data is as crucial as oil and gas for industry.

“It’s like with access to gas — if we make our entire energy supply rely on a few nations in the world who get to control access, we’re becoming politically dependent,” said Benjamin Strasser, a member of the German parliament for the liberal opposition Free Democrats (FDP). “It’s no different when it comes to data and data services.”

His warning is echoed by business leaders and engineers who caution that growing tensions between the U.S. and China have destabilized international business ties.

“In cloud computing, we rely on providers in the U.S. and China, who maintain a dominant position in providing cloud infrastructure,” said Karl-Heinz Streibich, a former CEO of Software AG and the president of the German Academy of Science and Engineering (Acatech).

“At the same time, we see tensions that affect trade, export and global supply chains — and this raises doubts, to say the least, if those countries will always act rationally in the future, including when it comes to dealing with other international partners,” Streibich added.

In a country that prides itself on a history of innovation, the comments reflect a growing awareness that much of the country’s administrative and industrial infrastructure runs on foreign technology.

Earlier this year, German car giant Volkswagen said it would use Amazon Web Services — the cloud service of the Seattle-based tech juggernaut, which dominates around a third of the global market — to connect its 122 plants around the world. The firm is also cooperating with Microsoft, the world’s No. 2 in the cloud market, to build up an “automotive cloud” to connect cars.

At the same time, American technology is used to support much of Germany’s public infrastructure — despite warnings by regulators that such moves pose a security risk.

Due to a lack of domestic alternatives, Germany’s federal police, for example, is storing its body camera footage on Amazon servers, with Germany’s highest data protection watchdog warning this could allow U.S. authorities to demand access to it.

Say hello to 'Gaia-X'

Chancellor Angela Merkel says she is concerned about the issue, and ready to respond.

Her longtime confidante, Economy Minister Peter Altmaier, has come up with a plan for a massive European cloud computing project to be named Gaia-X after the ancestral goddess and launched at the end of October in Dortmund.

Gaia-X is supposed to be a platform where European companies of all sizes can store, process and exchange data and cooperate on developing products, according to economy ministry officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the plans have not been officially announced.

The aim is to enable Europe and Germany's digital infrastructures to run independently if they were ever to be cut off from foreign cloud providers.

Technically, the idea is to establish what’s known as “hyperscaling” infrastructure, which can be adjusted according to demand. This, the ministry hopes, will guarantee European users that their data is “sovereign,” which the ministry defines as safe from foreign snooping and from being cut off for political reasons.

When Altmaier met his French counterpart Bruno Le Maire in the French capital last week, Le Maire said Paris supports the idea of a European cloud infrastructure, stressing that companies such as French industry giant Dassault could profit from such systems.

Although Le Maire did not mention “Gaia-X” by name, officials said that on a working level, the ministries in Berlin and Paris have already been discussing the idea.

U.S. tech giants have taken notice of such talk, and they’re pushing back.

In a blog post in German earlier this year, Microsoft Area Vice President Sabine Bendiek went all the way back to the Peace of Westphalia in 1648 to argue that by “isolating themselves,” Europe could end up falling further behind in technology.

But German lawmakers and corporate leaders are not deterred.

They say the effort does not aim to cut them off from global supply chains or end decades-old divisions of labor, but to enable Europe and Germany's digital infrastructures to run independently if they were ever to be cut off from foreign cloud providers.

“We observe on the political world stage that economic and technological dependencies are used as a form of leverage,” warned Acatech’s Streibich, who also chairs the German government’s platform for artificial intelligence and sits on the boards of German industry giants including Deutsche Telekom.

“We can’t rule out that our dependency from foreign cloud providers will be used as a means of exerting pressure on us.”

But can Europe do it alone?

Cloud computing allows companies to rent access from a provider and pay for the storage space they use, rather than maintain their own servers.

In recent years, it has become a key factor for companies and governments involved the global race for AI supremacy.

Previously, applying artificial intelligence had largely been a privilege of those who owned huge servers and had cutting-edge developers on staff — predominantly American and Chinese tech giants. But recently, those companies have begun to roll out some of their AI solutions to the masses, offering them as part of their cloud computing packages.

The applications, accessed via cloud computing, allow even mid-sized businesses in rural Germany, the backbone of the country’s economy, to boost their operations with AI, for example to analyze industrial data generated by its machines to optimize their performance.

The elephant in the room is whether the Continent is able to build developed cloud infrastructure on its own.

But the reality is that none of the providers offering those solutions are based in Europe.

“When it comes to cloud computing, we’re a digital developing country,” said FDP opposition lawmaker Strasser.

And whenever officials do call for similar cloud infrastructure in Europe, the elephant in the room is whether the Continent is actually able to build it itself.

“If we’re honest, we have to say that, technologically, other world regions are miles ahead of us in cloud computing,” Strasser said. “To build up a comparable system here will require lots of work — but we should at least start with that quickly.”

Streibich dismissed a similar question, saying that “it’s irrelevant whether we are currently already technically able to build up such an infrastructure — there's no question that we must enable ourselves to do it, and that we can enable ourselves to do it.”

“One question we should ask at the moment is which kind of infrastructure we want," he added.

The plan Berlin is pitching to the rest of Europe is becoming a world leader in building up digital infrastructure that focuses on industrial rather than consumer data.

This, the Continent’s economic powerhouse hopes, will allow it to be a world leader in a second wave of industrial artificial intelligence that is about to set off.
description: Europe’s largest economy relies on foreign cloud providers to store sensitive data. Leaders say that needs to change.
